replies.text: Enphase is good Anyone who believes in solar, EV charging themes, and power hungry data centers and A.I. needing renewable power, can look at ENPH. It generally has shown negative beta, and the stock seems to make random, out of sync moves compared to market. Today was an exception. Has shown strong buy volume spikes around 80.

I am heavily invested in ENPH. Here is what I know.. 1. ENPH is mostly residential. 65 of the revenue in the US and the rest is from EU. Theyre expanding in other parts of the world but revenue at the moment is still very low. They have recently introduced products for commercial as well, but revenue is still very negligible. 2. I am not certain about FSLR. They produce panels especially for utility scale. With the recent tariffs on panels imported from China, they seem to be more in play. 3. ENPH has a decent moat on the microinvertor tech, but their strength is their ecosystem invertors, battery, EV chargers and energy management last two still fairly new and I anticipate at some point in the future, theyll charge customers a monthly fee as they would help the customer save money on Energy management because of dynamic tariffs in various geos a few years away though. I havent invested in FSLR but I am definitely interested in it.
After reading this article, I decided to sit on the side lines and watch this time around. Just too many uncertainties. Good Luck.
RemindMe! 1 week

Havent invested in them but I have traded both. Ive noticed that while both are very interest rate sensitive FSLR seems to hold up better when there is bad interest rates news. Which makes me think they will do well in favorable interest rate environment Seems they still able to show some earnings in a bad environment for their industry. ENPH less so. They are both best in class in the industry but if I had to pick one for long term it would be FSLR but I havent done a deep dive into their fundamentals. I expect both will pop on cuts but I think FSLR will maintain the pop where ENPH will not because of there is a lot of people underwater on ENPH.

FSLR makes panels for utility scale solar. They dont do any residential. They are the industry leader in that segment in the US and have a multiyear backlog of orders. Their narrow moat is a proprietary panel design and manufacturing process that reduces the cost per watt and is much less energy intensive to build. Chinese manufacturers are heavily subsidized by the state, and are a risk to FSLRs moat. Current protectionist policies are keeping them from flooding the market and crashing prices, but if policy changes it could wipe out their moat.
The case against ENPH is that they dont really have any moat. Anyone can make what they make.

I would not equate all those things with Enphase. Residential, charging, storage yes. Utility level power including data centers is First solar. Im long Enphase. Both are the only investable solar companies to me.

As of September 2024, the West continues to impose heavy sanctions and restrictions on imports of many Russian goods, particularly in the wake of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. However, some Western countries still import specific Russian products, though in significantly reduced volumes compared to pre2022 levels. Key imports that continue to flow from Russia to Europe and the U.S. include 1. Energy Products Although many European countries have drastically cut their dependence on Russian natural gas and oil, certain imports like liquefied natural gas LNG still persist, albeit at reduced levels. 2. Metals Russian aluminum and derivative products are still imported, though the U.S. imposes a 200 tariff on aluminum and derivative products smelted or cast in Russia, and similar measures are applied to steel and other metals. 3. NonEnergy Commodities Certain agricultural products like fertilizers continue to be imported into Europe due to their critical role in food production. Overall, the proportion of Russian goods imported by the West has significantly decreased due to sanctions, tariffs, and a broader pivot away from reliance on Russian supply chains. The most prominent exceptions are energy and select raw materials, often subject to very high tariffs or specific exclusions. Several takeaways after this earnings call:  It is clear that the next 2 quarters (Q4 and 2025 Q1) are going to be a "turn-around" transition period for Enphase.  While that may shake some investors' confidence, I am hopeful.  Why ?  Because  Badri didn't shy from the analyst's question on their market share being pulled away from the Tesla Powerwall 3.  He did admit it was a problem, and they're are addressing the full backup market with the new 4th gen 10kW battery + the new meter collar that's coming out in 1Q 2025, and the new IQ9 inverters later in 2025.  They are also already engineering the next GaN system that can handle higher power at higher frequencies, both for the high-power system market (Brazil, etc) and medium power (US / Europe). Curious that 2 analysts asked about the solar market in India.  Both Badri and Rahgu commented on the fact the their current system (5P / IQ8) are primed to take market share in the luxury single-housing market there (smaller power systems, 10 kWhr max per day).. and they said ENPH can ship "old" inventories to India in 2025 + beyond, while pushing new models in the US market.  Incidentally, India's largest solar panel manufacturer just had a huge IPO just 2 days ago.   Plus, IEAE just opened their 2nd HQ in Singapore this year.  Ppl are saying that the SE Asian energy market will be a force to reckon with in 3 - 5 years.  If you have a 3-yr time horizon, I do feel that ENPH is heading in the right direction. Short-term pain?  Sure..

I find it very revealing how on this forum there is almost zero talk about the actual hardware that Enphase sells. 

Almost no one seems to realizes that with the disappearance of net metering and the advent of variable time of usage rates how important a battery storage, DC to DC charging and the grid tie interface has become. Unfortunately Enphase's micro inverters are not optimum for this type of system and that has in the past been their only real advantage. Their Grid tie interface/Battery storage system is too expensive, complicated in it's hardware and difficult to install along with the wrong size battery modules. 

they are working on trying to improve their solution for these problems and I am sure they will come up with something more competitive but the big question is when?

Folks if you will look at their actual product you will see why Enphase MUST quickly change to adapt to the new market conditions which ARE NOT RULED only by interest rates and any political results but by economics of the system function and cost. Everything else is just noise.

If you are counting on good news from FSLR to be the catalyst for Enphase's success then good luck with your investment strategy. You might have a little better luck investing if you try to analyze a company's product versus what consumers need versus what other companies are producing to satisfy the consumers need. This might give you a little better success rate. 

Kind of like Polaroid camera which once dominated the market and still took good and instant pictures but quickly went out of business when technology and consumer demand changed and they did not.

You have your reason why you think what you think, and I've got mine (which, at this point, I think share price action is most due to the past 3 quarters of depressed earnings due to macro conditions plus the pull-through of inventory in advance of NEM3.0 as well as supply chain issues from COVID/2022, as I've been saying for months now).  I think the enphase system works very well with net metering (I am net metered), but when net metering payback goes down (as in the move from NEM2.0 to NEM3.0 in CA), the Enphase system with batteries make it work even better for the homeowner than solar alone, which is why we're seeing attach rates go up. I know it's not available everywhere but will be soon.  Not just with Enphase.  Ford is piloting it with it's bidirectional charger. I have engaged with you before on this issue, but I still have to question -- where is the evidence of your assertion.  I have this system.  An older version of it, as I've talked about for years -- IQ7x on the roof and a 23kW of gen 2 batteries. I took your comments seriously, and I looked through my whole system, and I just don't see it.  Yes, the enclosures for the shut off switch is of off-the-shelf, but would you really expect any company anywhere to create their own, proprietary custom electrical box?  Literally, the only part that I could say yes, they cheaped out on, is maybe the USB stick that goes in an older system's gateway that uses zigbee to connect to wifi?  But even if that comm system goes down (and admittedly, it is wonky, and they don't use it anymore on new systems), the entire system still works, and net metering is completely unaffected.  The only implication is you may not be able to see the info on your app.  Ok, the cellular modem is a bit wonky, too, but it's the back up for the comm, and it going down does not affect your solar production, export, net metering, etc.  The most important part of the battery are the microinverters, and those are all Enphase all the way.  They're market-leading in terms of lowest error rates, and they have the longest warranties of any home solar battery in the world.  The interconnection device is pretty standard and works well, and the new one is even better (so I've heard - I have the old one and it's fine).

Why would ENPH (and some other solar stocks) be going down after the fed does an interest rate cut?  Higher interest rates were blamed for solar industry weakness, right?  Well...1.) An interest rate cut is typically followed by a J-curve, rather than a straight increase in post-cut demand.2.) Now that homeowners and home-builders know that we're finally in a rate cut cycle, it makes sense for them to wait for at least one or two more rate cuts before entering into solar contracts. Wouldn't you do the same thing if you were planning to finance an upcoming solar project? (This is part of the reason we see a J-curve after a cut).3.) The 4th quarter and 1st quarters are typically pretty weak for solar comparatively 4.) Oil futures are largely down over the year (look at CL=F for one such futures chart)5.)  Sunpower just went bankrupt, which added a whole lot of chaos in the residential solar market (many owners and installers wonder: who is servicing / honoring warranty on existing SPWR panels/sytem?).  Those are some of the reasons you may be seeing lower share prices.
Sell, eat your losses and buy a well diversified low cost S&P index fund from Schwab or Vanguard or SSGA.  At least you’ll start making some of your losses back.

Home owners in three parts of Zeeland who have solar panels on their roofs are being paid money to turn them off, RTL reported on Friday.

Grid manager Stedin and supplier Eneco hope the move, a first for the Netherlands, will reduce pressure on the national grid during sunny periods.

There are so many solar panels in the districts of Tholen, Sint Philipsland and Schouwen-Duiveland that more electricity is being generated than can be used, and that is causing capacity problems, the power companies say. If the experiment is a success, it will be extended to other parts of the country.
